p: The third shortcoming of this research has to do with the selection of predictor variables. Although we included a variety of psychological processes to study similarities and differences between endorsement of mitigation and adaptation, there are other potentially relevant variablesâ€”for example, the extent to which people believe that the proposed measures will be effective (i.e., efficacy beliefs [ 28, 30, 52]) and see themselves as personally capable of responding to climate change (i.e., self-efficacy beliefs [ 30, 35, 52]. Other relevant processes might include perceived costs of responses [ 52], experience with the effects of climate change [ 35], or beliefs and opinion of relevant others [ 28]. Studying these alternative predictors of endorsement of mitigation and adaptation could reveal that the motives to mitigate and to adapt vary more strongly than suggested by our findings.
